label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, May 17, 1944
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, responding to the last letter she received from him, delivering news of their friends, and informing him of her life in England.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
R 5 26 44
May 17th '44
Dear Sidney,
I notice on your letter on May 1st that you have written
Lt. Comdr. in the corner. You have never mentioned being promotedto
an other stripe. GONCRATULATIONS! Did all the Legendre boys get pro-
moted together? There must be many a bit of boasting if it did n't 
happen all three of you at once. When actually did this go through?
I know how slow the Navy is in ever promoting anyone so I am duely
impressed, and so pleased for you. Congratulate Brother Morris and
Brother Armant for me also.
Darling never mind about the bathing suit. I would much r
rather have the ear rings and as it is winter here again and there is
absolutely no hope of a swim unless I get to the French Riviera next winter-
it is honestly not worth while. I dont go to the country any more as one
can not travel anyhow, so there will be no opportunity to use one.
I am so pleased for you that you are enjoying yourself so
much. The party at the outrigger sounded heaven. I just cant immagine
anything more perfect than being out of doors under the moon near the
sea , and listening to soft sad Hawaiian music. It is from an other
world not this on in 1944. It hardly seems possible or real to me.
How lucky you are with no balck-out, and that perfect climate. I suppose
you adore it, and have some heavy"blond" who loves you very much.I dont
mean hevvy in pounds but only in weight of affection. Well I guess a
place like that without a gal is impossible. I hear Morris has a very
" heavy" one wso is nuts for him. I cant blame them[,]for the gals out there
have probably the two most attractive men in the world to play with, and
have had them both for nearly two years now. Well this spot is not quite
such a romantic setting,as you can picture. One drinks too much, works
too hard, and gets air -no_t at all, but all this wont last forever lets
hope, and some day this nightmare will be behind us.Anything to win this
d--- thing is the way I look at it.
I know we have been on the "brink" of invasion for months
and months,and I dont blame you for thinking that the navy will get to
India and France by the Pacific way before we get going, but hold every-
thing it is sure to come off some day in the future[,]and lets hope its a
howling success.It has got to be.
Charlie B. turned up yesterday back from an other paint
tour[,]and is off somewhere else again to-day on an othe[r] rassignement. He
makes me laugh so, and I love to see him turn up. He just leaves his laundry[,]
and is off again. He is breathless with enthusiasm over his life and every-
thing he is doing, and I do not believe anyone has a more interesting time
of it than he in this whole theatre.
Ellen Frazer the angel, has sent me some gay colored silk
dresses she picked up in P.B. from Tat Saunders[,]and I have got quite a
kick out of them. 
Rose sent me a c_olapsable umbrella that is a jem, and such
[End Page 1]
2
fun to put up and down. I keep meaning to buy Landene a birthday present
during the lunch hour but somehow so far have not got around to it. One
tries to do so much during the lunch hour, pick up cigarettes at P.X.,
get a shampo, eat, shot, etc etc. and consequently one gets nothing done
at all. Nothing opens till 9.30 and everything shuts at 5 P.M. so one misses
out all around.
You must be growing to terrific proportions to have to
move into a still bigger building.Are you becomming a very importent cog
in this great big wheal? I am a very rusty one, but our slogan is"We give
our all every hour on the hour for Eisenhower".
I am so gald your little Jap cook is such a success and
feeds you so well. I know what a difference it must make after so much
dog food and canned goods of Morris' choice. It's so much better for your
digestion to have a nice hot meal. It sounds so perfect breakfasting on
the terrace out of doors[,]and you dont know how I envy you. It all sounds
to good to be true. What I want more than anything is out of doors and
sunshine[,]and when this is over no one will even find me in doors for a
minute, not even at a desk long enough to sign a check. Whe[n] I think how
grim and dark I used to think the School House was down at Medway - it
makes me laugh. That was gay in comparison. I now keep a big vase filled
with lilacs and spring flowers on my desk to cheer me up, as I pass a
florist every morning on my way to the office.
I am still looking for an other flat with no success. I
am mean enough to hope my landlady will[not]be able to obtain passage back
to this the[a]tre. It may prove that I am right too.
My Big Boss is here but I have not seen him yet. He may
dine with me next week which would be fun. Serge saw a man who saw Janie[,]
and she is evidently O.K. somewhere. Thats all the news I know.
Laddie is in Mexic_o City visiting the President with
Mary. Winston is a marine private at Paris Island, and is devorcing Helena.
So long darling, take care of yourself. You did not
mention your ribs in your last letter so I hope they have meaneded by now.
Love-
Gertrude S Legendre
[End Page 2]
